awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  PIM/GMM--Micro-Manufacturing of Ceramics by Combining Powder Injection Molding and Green Micromachining
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research on fabrication of micro-scale ceramic structures by combining green-state micro-machining and powder-injection molding processes. The research objective is to gain fundamental knowledge on the combined process through integrated experimental and modeling studies. The specific research approach will include (1) analyzing the green micromachining process for different ceramic materials, powder and binder characteristics, and process parameters to determine their effect on process characteristics, including geometric quality and productivity, and (2) characterizing and modeling mechanical and geometric characteristics of parts fabricated using the combined process. The research will include aluminum-nitride and silicon-carbide as sample systems, and will demonstrate the effectiveness of findings by fabricating industrial ceramic parts. The educational objectives include enhancing the future manufacturing workforce, and improving existing manufacturing curricula, and attracting students to manufacturing through pre-college outreach activities.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to rapid, predictable, reproducible, low cost, and accurate manufacture of ceramic parts with micro-scale features. Ceramics offer many advantages such as high-temperature strength, chemical stability, thermal conductivity, and electrical insulation. Although the prevailing micro-fabrication technologies have been effective in creating micro-electronics components and sensors from semiconductor materials, we currently do not an effective micro-manufacturing technique to create three-dimensional micro-structures from ceramics. This approach will provide and effective way to make ceramic components with micro-structures, thereby facilitating exciting technological and scientific advances. Micro-scale ceramic devices and parts will benefit many industries, including medical devices, electronics/lighting systems, and clean energy technologies. The knowledge gained from this work will provide in-depth understanding of green micromachining and powder-injection molding processes to facilitate fabricating parts in a predictable fashion. Collaboration with industry and national laboratories will enable rapid transfer of research findings and our technology to industry, thereby impacting the advanced manufacturing industry. This research is also critical for the United States in its efforts to gain back the manufacturing leadership through advanced manufacturing efforts.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: University of Louisville Research Foundation Inc

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on enabling effective fabrication of three-dimensional (3D) micro-scale features on ceramics by synergistically combining green micromachining (GMM) and powder injection molding (PIM) processes. The main objective was to gain a fundamental understanding of the combined GMM/PIM process characteristics through an integration of carefully designed experiments and modeling. Although the prevailing micro-fabrication technologies have been effective in creating micro-electronics components and sensors from semiconductor materials, we did not have the viable capabilities to create micro-structures from ceramics when we undertook this collaborative work. While mechanical micromachining enables effective micro-manufacture of polymers and soft/easy-to-machine metals, it is not viable for fabrication of sintered ceramics due to process and tooling limitations. On the other hand, application of PIM (alone) at the micro scale poses significant practical and technological challenges, and has important geometric/material limitations. To this end, we developed and studied a combined PIM/GMM process that could eliminate the barriers to micro-molding of micro-structures with complex 3D geometries. In the combined PIM/GMM process, the first step is to fabricate green compacts by injection molding of a mixture of powdered ceramic with a polymer/wax binder. Next, GMM is applied by using micro-scale milling and drilling tools to create complex 3D structures at the micro scale, including undercuts, freeform surfaces, and high aspect ratio structures. Following GMM, parts are debound and sintered to obtain the final (full density) part with micro-scale features. Our overarching goal was to enable rapid, predictable, reproducible, low cost, and accurate production of ceramic parts with micro-scale features, thereby significantly expanding the current micro-manufacturing capability.   

Intellectual Merit: Our results demonstrate the feasibility, advantages  and challenges of the combined PIM/GMM process. Firther, an in-depth understanding of green micromachinability (material removal mechanisms, MRR, tool wear, process forces, and quality) was undertaked by our collaborator, B. Ozdognlar,  in Carnegie Mellon based on materials developed in our laboratort. Further correlation between the green and final part properties (thorough debinding and sintering) are on-going in order to make the PIM/GMM process and industrially viable technique for micro-manufacturing of ceramics. To this end, we addressed our main objective through two specific objectives: (1) By analyzing green micromachining for different powder and binder characteristics, green state, and micromachining conditions by conducting experimental analysis and modeling of material removal mechanism, feature quality, throughput, tool wear and forces; and (2) By determining and modeling the transformation of part characteristics from GMM to final sintered part through a blend of experimental and theoretical analyses of the debinding and sintering processes for each binder/powder type and different geometries. As representative (yet high impact) ceramics, we used AlN and SiC during experimental analyses and modeling. 

Broader Impacts: Ceramics offer many unique mechanical, thermal, chemical and electrical properties that make them ideal for a myriad of applications. However, the lack of effective micro-manufacturing techniques for ceramics significantly hinders scientific and technological advances in many fields. If successful, the work emerging from the combined PIM/GMM process will be a viable ceramic micro-manufacturing process for fabricating complex 3D shapes with high throughput for a broad range of applications.

The PI conducted a number of education/outreach activities to ensure societal impacts of the project, including incorporating research findings in 4 international workshops on powder injection molding and publishing a PIM market study for the industry

Two students completed their PhD dissertatons based on their contributions. The research group also published 8 refereed journal papers and presented 11 papers in international conferences. One of the graduated students is currently at the DOE NETL research laboratory in Albany, OR while the other is a tenure-track assistant professor at the Univeristy of Louisville.

The work allowed for exploring collaborations with industry, one particularly useful one being with Moldex3D in the area of process simulations for powder injection molding.

The ideas allowed for extension to other emerging powder and polymer  processes, especially in the field of 3D printing. As an example, a new 3D Printing Business Incubator hosting nearly 100 undergraduate design engineers annually was established at the Univeristy of Louisville (see uofl3dpbiz.com). The Fall 2016 semester batch included 7 women engineers, 3 African American engineers, and 3 Hispanic engineers. In this manner, new areas and under-represented minorities are being impacted following the growth of ideas and experiences emerging from the work.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2016
Modified by: Sundar V Atre

por.por_txt_cntn:
